question.de-DE: Wie hoch ist die Fluggeschwindigkeit einer unbeladenen Schwalbe?
question.en-US: What is the airspeed velocity of an unladen swallow?

content.value: Die Fluggeschwindigkeit einer unbeladenen Rauchschwalbe betrgt etwa 24 Meilen pro Stunde, also 11 Meter pro Sekunde. Dies geht aus einer Windkanalstudie von Lund hervor, bei der Vgel mit verschiedenen Geschwindigkeiten flogen.
The airspeed of an unladen European swallow is roughly 24 miles per hour, or 11 meters per second. This is based on a Lund wind tunnel study of birds flying at various speeds.

Die meisten PITs mit Gegengewicht verfgen ber ein Dreipunkt-Aufhngungssystem. Die Lenkachse des PIT ist mit einem Drehzapfen in der Mitte der Achse befestigt. Wenn diese drei Punkte mit imaginren Linien verbunden werden, entsteht das Stabilittsdreieck. Wenn der Schwerpunkt innerhalb des Stabilittsdreiecks bleibt, steht der PIT stabil und kann nicht umkippen. Ein unbeladener PIT auf einer ebenen Flche hat seinen Schwerpunkt in der Mitte des Stabilittsdreiecks. Wenn eine Last hinzugefgt wird oder wenn der PIT auf einer geneigten Flche steht, verschiebt sich der Schwerpunkt innerhalb des Stabilittsdreiecks. Wenn sich der Schwerpunkt auerhalb des Stabilittsdreiecks bewegt, kann das PIT umkippen.

Most counterbalanced PITs have a three-point suspension system. The PITs steer axle is attached by a pivot pin in the axles center. When these three points are connected with imaginary lines, the stability triangle is formed. When the center of gravity remains within the stability triangle, the PIT is stable and will not tip over. An unloaded PIT on a level surface will have a center of gravity in the middle of the stability triangle. As a load is added, or if the PIT is on an inclined surface, the center of gravity will move within the stability triangle. If the center of gravity moves outside of the stability triangle, the PIT may tip over.

teaser.de-DE: Verste gegen den PIT-Standard gehren jedes Jahr zu den zehn am hufigsten genannten OSHA-Standards.
teaser.en-US: Violations of the PIT standard rank in the top ten most frequently cited OSHA standards each year.

content.value: Die Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) definiert ein motorgetriebenes Flurfrderzeug (PIT) als ein mobiles, motorgetriebenes Fahrzeug, das zum Tragen, Schieben, Ziehen, Heben, Stapeln oder Schichten von Materialien verwendet wird, unabhngig davon, ob es von einem Fahrer gefahren oder von einem gehenden Fahrer gesteuert wird. Es gibt viele verschiedene Arten von (PITs), und jede Art birgt unterschiedliche Betriebsgefahren. PITs sind gemeinhin als Palettenhubwagen, Mitfahrwagen, Gabelstapler oder Hubwagen bekannt. Sie sind am Arbeitsplatz uerst ntzlich, wenn sie von geschulten Bedienern sicher eingesetzt werden.
Hintergrund

Die OSHA berarbeitete 1999 den allgemeinen Industriestandard PIT, 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.178, um Anforderungen an die Bedienerschulung aufzunehmen. Verste gegen den PIT-Standard gehren jedes Jahr zu den zehn am hufigsten genannten OSHA-Standards. Einer der Hauptgrnde ist mangelndes Training.
Anforderungen an die Sicherheitsschulung fr Gabelstapler

Arbeitgeber mssen ein Schulungsprogramm entwickeln und umsetzen, das auf den allgemeinen Grundstzen des sicheren Lkw-Betriebs, den verwendeten Fahrzeugtypen, den von ihnen ausgehenden Gefahren und den allgemeinen Sicherheitsanforderungen der OSHA-Norm basiert, um sicherzustellen, dass die Bediener ordnungsgem geschult werden. Geschult Die Bediener mssen wissen, wie sie die Arbeit ordnungsgem und sicher ausfhren, wie Arbeitsplatzbewertungen belegen. Es muss eine formelle (Vorlesung, interaktives Computerlernen, Video, schriftliches Material usw.) und praktische (Vorfhrungen durch den Trainer und praktische bungen durch den Auszubildenden) Schulung angeboten werden. Arbeitgeber mssen auerdem bescheinigen, dass jeder Bediener die Schulung erhalten hat, und die Leistung jedes Bedieners am Arbeitsplatz mindestens alle drei Jahre bewerten. Die Schulung muss von Personen durchgefhrt werden, die ber das Wissen, die Ausbildung und die Erfahrung verfgen, um PIT-Bediener auszubilden und ihre Kompetenz zu bewerten.
Inhalte des Schulungsprogramms

Bediener mssen zunchst in den folgenden LKW- und arbeitsplatzbezogenen Themen geschult werden, es sei denn, der Arbeitgeber kann nachweisen, dass das Thema nicht auf den sicheren Betrieb des PIT an seinem Arbeitsplatz anwendbar ist.
LKW-bezogen:
Betriebsanleitungen, Warnungen und Vorsichtsmanahmen fr die zu bedienenden Flurfrderzeugtypen
Unterschiede zwischen LKW und Pkw
Standort und Verwendung von PIT-Steuerungen und Instrumenten
Motor- oder Motorbetrieb
Lenken und Manvrieren
Sichtweite
Anpassung, Betrieb und Nutzungsbeschrnkungen von Gabel und Anbaugert
Fahrzeugkapazitt
Fahrzeugstabilitt
Vom Betreiber durchzufhrende Fahrzeuginspektion und -wartung
Betanken und/oder Laden und Wiederaufladen von Batterien
Betriebsbeschrnkungen
Weitere in der Bedienungsanleitung aufgefhrte Betriebsanweisungen, Warnungen oder Vorsichtsmanahmen
Arbeitsplatzbezogen:
Oberflchenbedingungen, unter denen PIT verwendet wird
Zusammensetzung und Stabilitt der Ladung
Ladungsmanipulation, Stapeln und Entstapeln
Fugngerverkehrsflchen
Schmale Gnge und andere Sperrbereiche
Betrieb an gefhrlichen (klassifizierten) Standorten
Arbeiten an Rampen und anderen geneigten Flchen
Der Betrieb des Fahrzeugs in geschlossenen Rumen oder anderen Bereichen, in denen eine unzureichende
Belftung zu Problemen fhren knnte
Andere einzigartige oder potenziell gefhrliche Umgebungsbedingungen

Da PITs von verschiedenen Unternehmen hergestellt werden und verschiedene Modelle zur Verfgung stehen, muss die Schulung speziell auf die Betriebseigenschaften des jeweils verwendeten PIT zugeschnitten sein. Wenn ein Bediener zuvor in einem der LKW- oder arbeitsplatzbezogenen Themen geschult wurde und die Schulung angemessen ist Je nach Fahrzeug und Arbeitsbedingungen ist eine zustzliche Schulung zu diesem Thema nicht erforderlich, wenn der Bediener beurteilt und fr kompetent befunden wurde.
Evaluierungs- und Auffrischungsschulung

Mindestens alle drei Jahre muss eine Bewertung der Leistung jedes PIT-Betreibers durchgefhrt werden. OSHA verlangt, dass unter bestimmten Umstnden eine formelle Auffrischungsschulung durchgefhrt wird. Es gibt keine festgelegte Hufigkeit, Arbeitgeber mssen jedoch eine Umschulung durchfhren, wenn:
Es wurde beobachtet, dass der Bediener das Fahrzeug auf unsichere Weise bediente.
Der Bediener war in einen Unfall oder einen Beinahe-Unfall verwickelt;
Der Bediener hat eine Bewertung erhalten, aus der hervorgeht, dass der Bediener das PIT nicht sicher betreibt.
Dem Bediener wird die Aufgabe bertragen, einen anderen PIT-Typ zu fahren; oder
Eine Situation am Arbeitsplatz verndert sich, was den sicheren Betrieb des PIT beeintrchtigen knnte.
Zertifizierung

Der Arbeitgeber muss bescheinigen, dass jeder Bediener eine angemessene Schulung erhalten hat, bewertet wurde und seine Kompetenz bei der Erfllung seiner Aufgaben nachgewiesen hat. Auf der Bescheinigung mssen der Name des Auszubildenden, das Datum der Schulung, das Bewertungsdatum und der Name der Person(en) enthalten sein, die die Schulung oder Bewertung durchfhrt.

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) defines a powered industrial truck (PIT) as any mobile, power-propelled truck used to carry, push, pull, lift, stack or tier materials, whether ridden by an operator or controlled by a walking operator. There are many different types of (PITs), and each type presents different operating hazards. PITs are commonly known as pallet trucks, rider trucks, forklifts or lift trucks. They are extremely useful in the workplace if they are safely used by trained operators.
Background

OSHA revised the PIT general industry standard, 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.178, in 1999 to include operator training requirements. Violations of the PIT standard rank in the top ten most frequently cited OSHA standards each year. One of the major citations is failure to train.
Forklift Safety Training Requirements

Employers must develop and implement a training program based on the general principles of safe truck operation, the types of vehicle(s) being used, the hazards they create and the general safety requirements of the OSHA standard to ensure that operators are properly trained.Trained operators must know how to do the job properly and safely, as demonstrated by workplace evaluations. Formal (lecture, interactive computer learning, video, written material, etc.) and practical (demonstrations by the trainer and practical exercises by the trainee) training must be provided. Employers must also certify that each operator has received the training and evaluate each operators performance in the workplace at least once every three years.Training must be conducted by persons who have the knowledge, training, and experience to train PIT operators and evaluate their competence.
Training Program Content

Operators must be initially trained in the following truck-related and workplace-related topics unless the employer can demonstrate that the topic is not applicable to the safe operation of the PIT in their workplace.
Truck-related:
Operating instructions, warnings, and precautions for the types of truck to be operated
Differences between the truck and automobiles
PIT controls and instrumentation location and use
Engine or motor operation
Steering and maneuvering
Visibility
Fork and attachment adaptation, operation, and use limitations
Vehicle capacity
Vehicle stability
Vehicle inspection and maintenance required to be performed by the operator
Refueling and/or charging and recharging batteries
Operating limitations
Other operating instructions, warnings, or precautions listed in the operator's manual
Workplace related:
Surface conditions where PIT will be used
Load composition and stability
Load manipulation, stacking, and unstacking
Pedestrian traffic areas
Narrow aisles and other restricted areas
Operation in hazardous (classified) locations
Ramp and other sloped surface operation
Operating the vehicle in closed environments or other areas where insufficient ventilation could cause problems
Other unique or potentially hazardous environmental conditions

Because PITs are manufactured by different companies with various models available, the training must be specific to the operating characteristics of the specific PIT being used.If an operator was previously trained on any of the truck or workplace-related topics, and the training is appropriate to the truck and working conditions encountered, additional training on that topic is not required if the operator has been evaluated and found competent.
Evaluation and Refresher Training

An evaluation of the performance of each PIT operator must be conducted at least every three years. OSHA requires that formal refresher training be conducted under certain circumstances. There is no set frequency, but employers do need to retrain when:
The operator has been observed to operate the vehicle in an unsafe manner;
The operator has been involved in an accident or near-miss incident;
The operator has received an evaluation revealing that the operator is not operating the PIT safely;
The operator is assigned to drive a different type of PIT; or
A condition in the workplace changes that could affect safe operation of the PIT.
Certification

The employer must certify that every operator has received appropriate training, has been evaluated and has demonstrated competency in performing their duties. The name of the trainee, date of training, evaluation date and name of the person(s) performing the training or evaluation must be included on the certification.
Quellen
29 CFR 1910.178, Powered Industrial Trucks
Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA), Powered Industrial Truck etool
Sources
29 CFR 1910.178, Powered Industrial Trucks
Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA), Powered Industrial Truck etool

title.de-DE: Professionelle Werkzeugsicherheit: 9 integrierte Funktionen und Vorteile, die Sie kennen sollten
title.en-US: Professional-Grade Tool Safety: 9 Built-In Features and Benefits to Know

teaser.en-US: What if your tools could prevent injuries before they happen?

content.value: What if your tools could prevent injuries before they happen?
In high-stakes industries, safety isn't just a priority  it's a necessity. According to the National Safety Council, construction workers reported over
144,000 non-fatal, days-away-from-work injuries
in 2021-22 and experienced the largest number of
preventable fatal injuries

compared to workers in other industries. Aaron Heilbrun, director of safety and industry trends at DeWalt noted, Construction remains an industry with a high number of injuries and fatalities, so theres still a lot of opportunity to improve."
Thanks to advancements in technology and material design, professional-grade tools now have many

features designed to help protect workers and provide increased productivity. From automatic shutoffs to anti-vibration technology and built-in hazard detection, these tools are setting a new standard in the workplace.
Professional-Grade Tools vs. Consumer Models

So, what makes professional-grade tools different from consumer models? It boils down to power, durability and features. Professional-grade tools have more power for more demanding projects and are designed to be more durable because they are used frequently, sometimes hours a day, every day, Aaron said. These tools are built for tough jobs and include features that go beyond what a consumer needs.

Philip Bolton, director of product management for metalworking and drywall at DeWalt, explained, "Safety in tools can be categorized into two main areas. One involves creating innovative methods, such as new wire stripping or cable cutting techniques that remove exposed blades. The other includes tools with proactive features like advanced software that maps performance and identifies potential hazards early." Many professional-grade tools increasingly incorporate these built-in features to help prevent issues before they become serious.
Key Features to Know
When picking professional-grade tools, look for features that balance safety with performance. Here are some key safety features to consider:
Brushless motors:
Professional tools often use
brushless motors,

which are generally more efficient than traditional brushed motors. Brushless motors often provide more power, longer battery life and require less maintenance. They also tend to run cooler, helping reduce the risk of overheating during extended use.
Electronic clutch:

An electronic clutch uses software to monitor the tools performance and can shut it off automatically. For example, if a high torque tool like an angle grinder experiences a bind up event, the electronic clutch can shut it down quickly, reducing the reaction torque the user feels.
Anti-vibration technology:
Using a tool that vibrates a lot can be tiring and even harmful over time. Anti-vibration technology helps reduce user fatigue and
prevent long-term injuries
like hand-arm vibration syndrome. When you're using a tool for an extended period, the vibration can add up and become uncomfortable for the worker," Aaron said.
Dust control systems:

Dust from materials like concrete and drywall can be harmful to your lungs. Many professional-grade tools offer compatibility with advanced dust control systems. This helps mitigate exposure to harmful dust and helps reduce respiratory issues. Professional tools have features like dust control systems to minimize risks associated with dust," Aaron said. These tools can also comply with regulations for dust management, such as
OSHA standard 1926.1153
Anti-rotation protection:

Anti-rotation features are designed to help stop tools from suddenly jerking back toward you. This is achieved by one of two ways, either with hardware such as a gyro or motor current mapping. Tools with anti-rotation features can quickly shut down if they bind, helping to reduce the risk of injuries, Philip explained.
Drop prevention solutions:

Some professional tools come with drop prevention features such as engineered tool lanyard connection points. These tether points help securely attach the tool to prevent it from falling and causing injuries. This is especially useful for individuals working at heights because if the tool is dropped, it automatically shuts off to help avoid accidents.
Anti-restart protection:

Many professional-grade tools have a feature that requires manual startup following a power interruption. Anti-restart protection is critical in preventing accidental startups that could cause serious injuries, Philip said.
Electronic brake systems:

Professional-grade tools, especially saws, often have electronic brake systems that can quickly stop the blade or bit after the trigger is released. The ability to quickly stop the tool can improve productivity and help prevent accidents, Philip noted.
Application-specific tools:

Professional-grade tools are often designed for specific tasks. For example, a 20-volt cable stripper is made specifically for cutting cables, eliminating the need for exposed blades and reducing the risk of cuts. Other tools like cable tray cutters are designed to cut cable trays with more control than grinders or band saws.
Why These Features Matter

These features can make a real difference on the job. For example, anti-vibration technology and dust control systems are especially useful during long drilling tasks, where exposure to dust and fatigue are significant concerns. Anti-rotation and electronic clutches are also important when using high-torque tools because they are designed to reduce uncontrolled motion that could cause serious injuries.

In some professional grade models, we've incorporated features like dual triggers that ensure two-handed operation when in use, Philip explained. These features are designed to help the user maintain control.

When picking professional-grade tools, also consider power needs, ergonomics and overall battery life. Pro-grade tools often come with enhanced grip surfaces made of materials designed to provide more comfort to the end user.
We constantly gather feedback from our users," Phillip said. "This information is critical in guiding our product development to address real-world needs and improve safety features."
The Role of Emerging Technologies

Investing in professional-grade tools is more than just meeting safety regulations  its about creating a more efficient work environment. With advanced features like anti-vibration technology, dust control systems and electronic clutches, professional-grade tools can help boost workplace productivity.
Aaron also called out the construction industry's
significant labor shortage
. Having power tools that are easier to operate can help bridge the labor gap, making worksites safer for everyone involved.

Looking ahead, AI and machine learning may further enhance tool safety through predictive maintenance and real-time hazard detection. Aaron noted, Avoiding a safety incident is far better than addressing it after the fact. Tools that can communicate events to allow for quick intervention are incredibly promising.

As regulations become more complex and insurance costs rise, investing in health and safety is crucial. Aaron said: "OSHA estimates that for every $1 invested in health and safety, a company gets $4 to $6 back in terms of fewer safety events, lower insurance premiums, and projects remaining on time and on budget. Safe workers are productive, and productive workers are profitable."

question.de-DE: Was ist der Unterschied zwischen einem Schlagschrauber und einem Schlagschrauber?
question.en-US: What is the difference between an impact driver and impact wrench?

content.value: Schlagschrauber sind in der Regel kleiner (mit 1/4"-Sechskantantrieb) und eignen sich zum Eindrehen kleinerer Schrauben. Schlagschrauber sind grer und liefern mehr Kraft und haben in der Regel einen 3/8"-Vierkantantrieb und mehr. Schlagschrauber sind in der Regel zum Lsen und Befestigen groer Schrauben und Muttern geeignet.

Sie funktionieren beide auf hnliche Weise - sie verwenden eine rotierende Hammerwirkung, um das Befestigungselement zu verdrehen. Im Vergleich zu einer herkmmlichen Bohrmaschine oder Ratsche, die eine kontinuierliche Kraft ausbt, knnen Schlagschrauber und -schrauber viel mehr Kraft ausben, indem sie die Kraft in mehreren kurzen, aber krftigen Schlgen in einer Art Drehbewegung pulsieren lassen. Dies fhrt zu einem geringeren Reaktionsdrehmoment (das Werkzeug versucht, sich aus der Hand zu ziehen), zu weniger abgeschlagenen Schraubenkpfen und zu einer viel hheren Leistung - ntzlich beim Eindrehen langer oder festsitzender Schrauben/Bolzen.

Impact drivers are usually smaller (using 1/4" hex drive) for driving in smaller screws. Impact wrenches are larger and deliver more power, and are usually 3/8" square drive and larger. Impact wrenches are usually for loosening and fastening large nuts and bolts.

They both operate in a similar manner- they use rotational hammering action to twist the fastener. Compared to a traditional drill or ratchet that applies continuous force, impact drivers and wrenches are able to exert much more force by "pulsing" the force in a twisting fashion, in several short, but powerful blows. This results in less reactionary torque (tool trying to pull out of your hands), less stripped screwheads and much higher power- useful for driving long, or stuck screws/bolts.

question.de-DE: Was sind die Vorteile eines brstenlosen Motors?
question.en-US: What are the benefits of a brushless motor?

content.value: Bei PowerToolz sind wir sehr stolz auf die Qualitt all unserer Produkte fr den Endverbraucher, und mit der Einfhrung von brstenlosen Elektrowerkzeugen durch unsere Profiwerkzeugabteilung, die den Weg vorgibt, hat B&D nun mit dem LST540 String Trimmer mit dem Einsatz der brstenlosen Technologie begonnen, und Sie knnen in Zukunft noch mehr erwarten.
Ein brstenbehafteter Motor verwendet Brsten und einen Kommutator, um die Magnetspulen des Ankers mit Strom zu versorgen. Dies kann zu Reibung, Hitze und Energieverlusten an der Kontaktstelle fhren.

Bei einem brstenlosen Motor hingegen entfallen der Kommutator und die Brsten und damit auch die Reibung, die bei einem herkmmlichen Motor entsteht. Dieses Design sorgt fr einen effizienteren, khleren Motor und geringeren Verschlei.
Die sprbarsten Vorteile des brstenlosen Designs sind also
Weniger Wartungsaufwand (keine Brsten, die ausgetauscht werden mssen)
Lngere Lebensdauer des Motors (aufgrund des khleren Betriebs)
Mehr Leistung
Lngere Laufzeit mit der gleichen Batterie

At PowerToolz we take great pride in the quality of all of our consumer products, and with our professional tool division launching brushless power tools to lead the way, B&D has now begun the use of brushless technology with the LST540 String Trimmer and you can expect more as we move into the future.
A brushed motor uses brushes and a commutator to supply electricity to the magnetic coils of the armature. This can create friction, heat, and loss of energy at the point of contact.

With a brushless motor, however, we do away with the commutator and brushes, and thus, the friction generated on a more common motor. This design allows for a more efficient, cooler motor and less wear and tear.
So the more noticeable benefits of the brushless design will be
Less maintenance (no brushes that need to be replaced)
Longer motor life (due to cooler operation)
More Power
Longer Runtime from the same battery

question.de-DE: Knnen Elektrowerkzeuge bei Nsse verwendet werden?
question.en-US: Can power tools be used in wet conditions?

content.value: Elektrowerkzeuge drfen nicht in nassen Umgebungen verwendet werden, egal unter welchen Umstnden. Kabelgebundene und kabellose Werkzeuge arbeiten mit Strom, der in nasser Umgebung nicht funktioniert. Zum Beispiel sollten Elektroschleifer nicht zum Nassschleifen verwendet werden. Die Verwendung eines Elektrowerkzeugs (kabellos oder kabelgebunden) unter solchen Bedingungen kann zu Stromschlgen, Verletzungen, Tod, Feuer und/oder Sachschden fhren.
Die einzige Ausnahme bilden bestimmte Fliesensgen, die ber die erforderliche Konstruktion und den erforderlichen Schutz verfgen, um in einer nassen Umgebung verwendet zu werden.
Lesen Sie immer die Bedienungsanleitung fr den richtigen Gebrauch und die Sicherheit des Werkzeugs!

Power tools cannot be used in any type of wet condition regardless of the circumstance. Corded and Cordless tools operate with electricity which do not work in wet conditions. For example, powered sanders should not be used for wet sanding. Using a power tool (cordless or corded) in such conditions may result in shock, personal injury, death, fire and/or property damage.
The only exception would be certain tile saws- which have the necessary design and protection to be used in a wet environment.
Always consult the owner's manual for proper tool use and safety!
